Epstein Flight Log 2003: Three Continents of Travel

The 2003 flight logs show Jeffrey Epstein's operation at its most expansive. During this year, his aircraft crisscrossed North America, Europe, and the Caribbean with remarkable frequency. The manifests document connections to powerful figures and institutions that would later come under scrutiny.

Scope of 2003 Aviation Activity

The 2003 logs reveal extensive use of Epstein's aviation resources:
  • North American routes - Frequent US-Canada-Mexico travel
  • European destinations - Regular London and Paris visits
  • Caribbean circuit - Constant US Virgin Islands access
  • Special destinations - Occasional trips to unusual locations
The breadth of travel demonstrates Epstein's global reach and the resources supporting it.

Primary Airports in 2003 Logs

The 2003 manifests show regular use of specific airports:
  • Teterboro Airport (TEB) - New Jersey base near Manhattan
  • Palm Beach International (PBI) - Florida residence access
  • Cyril E. King (STT) - St. Thomas, gateway to his island
  • Le Bourget (LBG) - Paris business aviation airport
  • Luton Airport (LTN) - London area landings
  • Santa Fe Municipal (SAF) - New Mexico ranch
These airports correspond directly to Epstein's property holdings.

Notable 2003 Travel Patterns

Several significant patterns appear in the 2003 logs:

The Weekend Circuit: Friday departures to Palm Beach or the Caribbean with Sunday returns to New York.

Extended European Trips: Week-long or longer visits involving multiple European cities.

Guest Collection Flights: Evidence of routing to pick up passengers from different locations.

Island Access: Regular flights to St. Thomas followed by transfers to Little Saint James.

Passenger Analysis for 2003

The 2003 manifests include several categories of passengers:
  • Regular companions - Ghislaine Maxwell and staff members
  • Young women - Often listed by first name only
  • Business figures - Financial industry contacts
  • Academic visitors - Scientists and researchers
  • Political figures - Various elected officials and diplomats
  • Celebrity guests - Entertainment industry names
The mix of passengers reflects Epstein's diverse social network.

2003 Context and Significance

In 2003, Epstein remained completely unknown to law enforcement. His finances were unexamined. His properties were private. This freedom allowed his travel patterns to develop without any attempt at concealment or modification.

The 2003 logs are therefore particularly valuable for understanding the natural operation of his network. They show destinations, timing, and passenger combinations that reflect genuine priorities rather than responses to external pressure.
The 2003 flight logs document a year of extensive global movement across Epstein's network. The manifests show connections spanning business, academia, politics, and entertainment. These records provide crucial insight into how his operation functioned during its period of complete secrecy, establishing patterns that would later help investigators understand the full scope of his activities.
